docs.title:
Welcome to BanIELTSg! ❤️

Hey IELTS Crew!

Welcome to your ultimate IELTS hangout. Here, I've gathered all my favorite resources, tips, and tricks that helped me crush the test. Whether you're aiming for a top score or just getting started, this place has got you covered. Dive in, explore, and let's nail those IELTS goals together!

A significant amount of knowledge on this website has been collected from Võ Đức Toàn (Anh ngữ Toàn Đạt - TOEIC, IELTS, VSTEP B1) ❤️.
Web mapping
docs.text:
• Home
  • Notebook
    • Writing
    • Speaking
    • Reading
    • Listening
  • Synonyms (keyword table)
    • Topic
  • Part of speech
  • Practical

Wishing you success and confidence on your IELTS journey!

docs.title: FULL TESTS - tuhocielts.dolenglish.vn
docs.text: This link provides access to free IELTS online tests, enabling learners to practice and prepare for the IELTS exam. It includes various sections such as Listening, Reading, Writing, and Speaking to offer a comprehensive practice experience.

docs.title: WRITING - zim.vn
docs.text: This page offers a compilation of the latest IELTS Writing tests for 2023, complete with sample answers. It helps learners understand the current trends and difficulty levels of the exam, providing a valuable resource for effective preparation.

docs.title: SPEAKING - ome.tv
docs.text: OME.tv is a platform that connects users via video chat, offering an excellent opportunity for IELTS Speaking practice. Users can engage in real-time conversations with people from around the world, improving their speaking skills and gaining confidence.

docs.title: READING - tuhocielts.dolenglish.vn
docs.text: This link leads to a collection of IELTS Reading practice materials. It includes various passages and questions designed to simulate the actual IELTS Reading test, helping learners enhance their reading comprehension and test-taking strategies.

docs.title: LISTENING - tuhocielts.dolenglish.vn
docs.text: Here, learners can find a range of IELTS Listening practice exercises. These resources provide realistic listening tasks similar to those found in the IELTS exam, aiding in the development of listening skills and familiarity with the test format.

docs.title: LISTENING DICTATION - dailydictation.com
docs.text: Daily Dictation offers exercises aimed at improving listening and dictation skills. This site provides various audio recordings along with transcription tasks, helping learners sharpen their ability to understand spoken English and improve their spelling and grammar.

docs.title: Alphatbet
docs.text: Letter IPA Audio A /eɪ/ B /biː/ C /siː/ D /diː/ E /iː/ F /ɛf/ G /dʒiː/ H /eɪtʃ/ I /aɪ/ J /dʒeɪ/ K /keɪ/ L /ɛl/ M /ɛm/ N /ɛn/ O /oʊ/ P /piː/ Q /kjuː/ R /ɑːr/ S /ɛs/ T /tiː/ U /juː/ V /viː/ W /ˈdʌbəl.juː/ X /ɛks/ Y /waɪ/ Z /ziː/ (American) or /zɛd/ (British)

docs.title: Numbers
docs.text: Number IPA 0 /zɪəroʊ/ (American) or /ˈzɛrəʊ/ (British) 1 /wʌn/ 2 /tuː/ 3 /θriː/ 4 /fɔːr/ 5 /faɪv/ 6 /sɪks/ 7 /ˈsɛvən/ 8 /eɪt/ 9 /naɪn/

docs.title: Questions
docs.text:
• Audio-tracking \(\leftrightarrow\) Word the same.
  • Answer-locating \(\rightarrow\) Synonyms \(\rightarrow\) click

docs.title: Answers
docs.text:
• Related words (contextualize) \(\rightarrow\) click

  • Synonyms \(\rightarrow\) click

    Note

    Answer synonyms appear very rarely.

Example

  1. Community groups are mainly concerned about . . .
    • A. pedestrian safety
    • B. traffic jams
    • C. increased pollution
  • Audio-tracking \(\rightarrow\) Community
  • Answer-locating
    • mainly \(\rightarrow\) the most important, mostly, primarily, key
    • concerned \(\rightarrow\) worry, care, afraid
  • Answers
    • A \(\rightarrow\) pedestrian \(\rightarrow\) walk, children. safety \(\rightarrow\) accident, car crash ~ collision, pavement ~ sidewalk, crimes, vehicles,...
    • B \(\rightarrow\) traffic jams \(\rightarrow\) congestion, rush hours, peak hours, noisy, crowded, jam-packed, gridlock, large number of vehicles,... late, annoy, narrow streets, city center, downtown area,...
    • C \(\rightarrow\) increased pollution \(\rightarrow\) contamination, dirty, rubbish ~ trash ~ garbage, littering, gas emissions, factories,... impacts …

docs.title: Locating words
docs.text:
• Geographical location ⛰️
  • Name of an academic 🧪
  • History period ⏲️
  • Title of a publication 📰
  • Date of a study / survey 📅
  • Species / An animal 🐶
  • Terminology 📘

docs.title: Words with similar meanings (contextualized)
docs.text:
• Synonyms (keyword table) \(\rightarrow\) Click here.
  • Part of speech (word form) \(\rightarrow\) Click here.

Example

The study by Canadian scientists in 2011 made a surprising discovery. \(\rightarrow\) "...and this was a finding that was completely unexpected." 

1. surprising ~ unexpected
2. discovery ~ finding

docs.title: Rules
docs.text:
1. Pick the exact words in the text.
  2. Word limit (NO MORE THAN WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER).
  3. Part of Speech \(\rightarrow\) Click here.
  4. Words with similar meanings \(\rightarrow\) Click here.

Failure

  • Vượt số lượng từ cho phép.
  • Từ đã được paraphrase.

Example

  • Text: personal information
  • Answer: Any information related to yourself must be kept in secret.

\(\rightarrow\) related to yourself = personal

docs.title: Noun 🧒
docs.text:
• Đếm được
    • Số ít ➡️ a/an + N.
    • Số nhiều ➡️ to be.
  • Không đếm được ➡️ to be.

docs.title: Verb 🏃
docs.text:
The same.

Note

Intransitive ➡️ V. Transitive ➡️ V + O.

docs.title: Adj 🥀 / V3ed (passive) 💥
docs.text:
• To be + Adj
  • Adj + Noun
  • Linking verb + Adj
  • make / find / keep + Adj
  • leave + O + Adj
[Table](../wordform/index.md){ .md-button .md-button--primary }

docs.title: The vibe
docs.text:
• Positive 👍
  • Negative 👎
  • Neutral 👐

docs.title: The theme
docs.text:
• Comparison \(\rightarrow\) comparison structures. 💁
  • Contrast \(\rightarrow\) constrast linking verb (However,...).
  • Money 💰
  • Physical aspects \(\rightarrow\) body. 👄👂👀
  • Brain \(\rightarrow\) neural,... 🧠

docs.title: Indicating time
docs.text:
• Present tense \(\rightarrow\) currently/present/at the moment
  • Early \(\rightarrow\) past/historic/ston age/medieval/century/V2/ed
  • Future \(\rightarrow\) upcoming/anticipations/long-term

docs.title: Noun
docs.text:
• Synonyms/contextualized \(\rightarrow\) Click here

    Example

    • change \(\rightarrow\) redesign, improve
    • effect (impact) \(\rightarrow\) increase/decrease

  • Generalization \(\rightarrow\) Specific objects.

    Example

    • Innovative devices \(\rightarrow\) laptops, computers, cell phones,...
    • Science subjects \(\rightarrow\) Mathematics, Physics, Geogarphy,...

docs.title: Adjective
docs.text:
\(\rightarrow\) Only synonyms.

Example

basic ~ fundamental ~ significant ~ radical

docs.title: Classification
docs.text:
Note

No highlight if all same type.

**CLASSIFICATION TABLE FOR NEWBIE** [DOWNLOAD PDF](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1HaPC5L9xl3wfFG2uksrHDW7OiQYnl5dl/view?usp=share_link){ .md-button .md-button--primary }

docs.title: SPEAKING
docs.text:
Info

  • Pronunciation \(\rightarrow\) 9
  • Fluency and Coherence \(\rightarrow\) 9
  • Lexical Resources (vocab) \(\rightarrow\) 9 \(\rightarrow\) topic-related vocab + academic language
  • Grammatical Range + Accuracy \(\rightarrow\) 9
[Intonation](https://www.learn-english-today.com/pronunciation-stress/intonation.html){ .md-button .md-button--primary }

docs.title: Idea development
docs.text:
• Like \(\rightarrow\) yes \(\rightarrow\) particular type \(\rightarrow\) reason (topic-related vocab + cohenrence) \(\rightarrow\) feeling / frequency.
  • Dislike \(\rightarrow\) no \(\rightarrow\) reason (related info / personality) \(\rightarrow\) general feelings / alternative (another choice).

Tip

  • Double tense (past - present).
  • Structure highlights:
    • (Not) have a strong liking (penchant) for
    • Be (not) really into + N/Ving
    • Be an (a) avid (big fan) of st
    • Be (not) an avid + Noun-er (reader, runner, traveler,...)
    • St be my Noun of choice
    • My favorite + Noun \(\rightarrow\) My go-to + Noun

Tip

  • Trick: Hobbies \(\rightarrow\) Present perfect.

docs.title: Liking
docs.text:
• Well, I'm quite satisfied with , and one particular thing I do enjoy is + N-Phrase (that SVO)

  • There are quite a number of (several) things I really enjoy about , but what I find most enjoyable is + N-Phrase (that SVO).

docs.title: Disliking
docs.text:
• One particular thing I don't like about is . It's something that's been bugging me a lot recently.

  • There are quite a number of (several) things I don't really enjoy about , but what really annoys me all the time is + N-Phrase (that SVO).

  • Well, I'm not satisfied with , and one particular thing I don't enjoy is + N-Phrase (that SVO)

  • Well, I'm quite satisfied with , but it doesn't mean there is no room for improvement

  • What I find really annoying is + N-Phrase (that SVO)

Tip

  • After the complaint, putting the ALTERATION:
    • If given a chance, i would
    • I wish + subject could/would

docs.title: Structures
docs.text: Do you like (prefer) A or B ?

docs.title: 1 of the 2 options
docs.text:
• I would probably 😕 (definitely 💯) go for (opt for) paraphrasing / the former / the latter
  • I'm more inclined 😗 to V
  • I lean towards 😗 A/B

docs.title: It depends
docs.text:
• It kinda (sorta) depends 💁‍♂️
  • It depends (would depend) on + factor❗
  • If case 1 ➡️ A, If case 2 ➡️ B

docs.title: Neither
docs.text:
• Well, maybe (probably) neither of them 🙅‍♂️ ➡️ reasons + personal choice
  • Could I say neither of them? 😉 ➡️ reasons + personal choice

Note

  • Comparision / contrast language.
  • Discuss both sides.

docs.title: Part 2
docs.text:
Info

  • Describe question.
  • Length: 1'45s - 2' (230 words)
  • Flow: fluency + cohenrence (explanation)

docs.title: Lead-in
docs.text:
• Lead-in (optional): Background information \(\rightarrow\) introduce the topic (specific).

Note

Paraphrase the topic.

  • Structures:
    • When it comes to +
    • Speaking of topic (paraphrase), the first one popping up in my mind is ...
    • Speaking of topic (paraphrase), the first off the top of my head is ...
    • It reminds me of the time when ... (experience & specific situation)

Note

  • Short
  • Friendly

docs.title: Background information (peripheral details)
docs.text: Talk about the background information (peripheral details).

docs.title: Key details (address the key words)
docs.text:
Define the keywords

  • Key 1: general fact to define the key words

    Note

    Using present tense

  • Key 2:

    • Particular feature (highlight)

      Example

      • What sets ... apart from others?
      • What would distinguish him/her from other people?
      • What is the most fascinating feature?

    • Short story

      Example

      • I still remember vividly that ...
      • If I remember correctly, ...

docs.title: Job
docs.text:
Abstract

Describe a job that you do not like to do in the future.

  • child 👶 ➡️ childhood dream ➡️ harbor a dream of Ving ➡️ ❓why❓
  • as I grow older 👨‍🦲 ➡️ change mindset ➡️ It's just dawned on me that ➡️ ❓reasons❓
  • be not born to become noun 🙅‍♂️
  • have no knack for Ving 💃
  • do not have (possess) what it takes to become noun 🙅‍♂️
  • be too adj (physically / mentally) demanding for me 💥

docs.title: Complaining
docs.text:
Abstract

Describe an occasion when you heard someone complaining about something in a restaurant / store or other business places.

  • witness a significant complaint 👀
  • show dissatisfaction 💢
  • make a complaint 💬
  • insist on Ving 💢
  • tick (piss) someone off ➡️ ticked (pissed) me off ➡️ I got pissed off (nothing is more important than hygiene) 😠
  • make a fuss 📢
  • complain bitterly 🤦‍♂️
  • lose one's cool ➡️ shout at / yell at 🔊
  • offensive language 😡

docs.title: Online video
docs.text:
Abstract

Describe an online video where you learned something new

The lead-in introduces the topic by briefly mentioning how I watched a cooking video for a family party, while the background information provides details about why I chose to watch the video and what made it relevant to the occasion.

  • Lead-in: a cooking video for a family party.
  • Background information: why I chose to watch the video and what made it relevant to the occasion.

When it comes to learning from online videos, the first one that comes to my mind is a cooking tutorial, specifically on how to make a simple steak. I watched this video a few months ago on YouTube for my family party.

Speaking of cooking steak, this video was the first off the top of my head because I wanted to impress my family with a perfectly cooked meal. I still remember colorfully that I needed something easy to follow, yet tasty enough to serve at the party. So, I found this video, which broke down step-by-step in a very clear and friendly way.

What sets this video apart is how the chef Gordon Ramsay showed the key techniques, like getting the perfect sear, timing the cooking process, and properly seasoning the steak. It also included tips on how to rest the meat after cooking, which I hadn’t thought about before.

After following the video, I learned how to cook a medium rare and juicy steak that was a big hit with my family. It boosted my confidence in preparing meals for gatherings and taught me the importance of paying attention to small details in cooking.

docs.title: Clause
docs.text: S + V + (O) - Verb: - Intransitive \(\rightarrow\) SV (E.g. Work). - Transitive \(\rightarrow\) SVO (E.g. Do).

docs.title: N-phrases
docs.text:
• Pre-modifier:
    • ADJ + N \(\rightarrow\) Characteristic.
    • N + N \(\rightarrow\) Featuring/Platform.
  • Post-modifier:
    • N + Ving/V3ed \(\rightarrow\) Reduced form of relative clause.

docs.title: Synonyms
docs.text:
• Condition:
    1. Part of speech
    2. Meaning

Example

  • State-of-the-art / Cutting-edge + N ➡️ Máy móc, công nghệ, thiết bị, dụng cụ, phát minh, ứng dụng, thiết kế tiên tiến, tối tân.
  • Contemporary + N ➡️ Suy nghĩa, điệu múa, âm nhạc, văn hoá, xã hội, lối sống, nền văn minh, con người.

docs.title: Part of speech / Word form
docs.text:
• Step 1. Define word having family words.
  • Step 2. Translate to Viet sentence obtained family words.
  • Step 3. Translate to Eng.

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
TOPIC SENTENCE STRUCTURE POPULARITY 📈 - An increasing number of noun have a tendency to verb. - During the past few years, noun has become increasingly popular. - Over the last decades, noun has gained increasing popularity. 2 VIEWS 👀 - A school of thought holds that . - Some opine that . - Some are of the opinion that . - Some hold a firm belief that .

Note

Modal verb (should, could,...) ➡️ passive voice

docs.title: Chart type
docs.text:
• bar / column
  • line
  • pie
  • table

docs.title: Variable type
docs.text:
• Time period
  • Discrete categories

docs.title: Units
docs.text:
• , \(\rightarrow\) separation. e.g. 100,000,000
  • . \(\rightarrow\) decimal. e.g. 1.5

Example

5 thousand dollars, 300 million cars, 15.7%.

docs.title: Preposition
docs.text:
Preposition Location Note Example from year x to year y - Subject Verb Adv + from x to y - There was a adj noun (key trend) + from x to y - categories witnessed (saw/ experenced) a adj noun (key trend) in subject + from x to y Adding specific year - from x in year X to y in year Y - from x to y between year X and year Y - The number of cars sold in the UK increased sharply from 10 million to 20 million cars between 1980 and 1985. TIME - during - over - in - throughout TIME + the x years -first - next - following - last bonus: 10 years \(\rightarrow\) a decade, 20 years \(\rightarrow\) 2 decades - UK witnessed a sighnificant increase in car sales from 5 million to 10 million cars in the first 5 years. at value point - start (begin/ stand)/ finish (end)/ peak + at value point - remained unchaged (stable/ constant) + at value point - don't miss V3/ed begin \(\rightarrow\) began - peak at = hit (reach) a peak of - In 1980, car sales in UK started at 10 million cars. to figure Verb Adv + to (only/merely) figure - Over the next 10 years, car sales decreased significantly to only 5 million cars in 1995. from figure x to figure y noun/verb + from x to y - Over the next 20 years, there was a significant drop from 30 million cars to merely 10 million cars in 1990. - Over the next 20 years, car sales declined sharply from 20 million cars to merely 5 million cars in 1995. by / of figure x to figure y - verb + by - noun + of - Apply for interval value. - by/of + approximately (roughly) x to (only/merely) y - Over the next 10 yeas, car sales declined sharply by roughly 15 million cars to merely 5 million cars in 1995. - Over the next 10 years, there was a significant drop of roughly 15 million cars to merely 5 million cars in 1995.

Note

  • NUMBER-FOLD (THREEFOLD / TENFOLD / FIVEFOLD)
    • E.g. increased threefold
  • Double / triple / quadruple

docs.title: Structure reducing
docs.text:
Original Changing to Note Example Subject Verb_1 and Verb_2 Subject Verb_1, Verb_2-ing V1 and V2 is the same subject - In 1980, car sales in UK started at 10M cars, and then this figure rose sharply and peaked at 20M cars in 1985. -> In 1980, car sales in UK started at 10M cars, and then this figure rose sharply, peaking at 20M cars in 1985. SVO, and then this figure + key trend IN 1990, THE PROPORTION OF I USERS EXPERIENCED A MARGINAL DECLINE TO 27.8%, and then this figure LEVELED OFF UNTIL THE END OF THE PERIOD. SVO + year, after which the figure (X) + key trend THE PROPORTION OF I USERS EXPERIENCED A MARGINAL DECLINE TO 27.8% IN 1990, after which this figure LEVELED OFF UNTIL THE END OF THE PERIOD. SVO (data), which + key trend IN 1990, THE PROPORTION OF I USERS EXPERIENCED A MARGINAL DECLINE TO 27.8%, which LEVELED OFF UNTIL THE END OF THE PERIOD.

Note

  • FOLLOWED BY ... to ...

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Abstract

  • Paraphrase the task.
    • Synonyms.
    • Part of speech \(\rightarrow\) word form.
  • Changing the sentence structures.

docs.title: Basic
docs.text: ORIGINAL CHANGING TO NOTE graph / diagram - the given - the provided : line graph, bar chart, column chart, pie chart below omitted show - illustrate - depict - compare - contrast don't miss s if several. information about data on in the subject under survey (not important) - time period \(\rightarrow\) : the changes - without time period \(\rightarrow\) : the differences from year to year - between and - over the course of years from to - during the period spanning from to in \(\rightarrow\) in the year

docs.title: Subject under survey
docs.text:
ORIGINAL CHANGING TO EXAMPLE (data/figures) - the number of noun (countable) + Ving/3ed - the amount of noun (uncountable) + Ving/3ed - the proportion (percentage/rate) of noun + Ving/3ed - How much/many subject + be v3ed - the amount of money invested - the amount of money earned - the proportion of people using the local library - the amount of gas emitted from 2 different private vehicles. - how much oil was produced subject A in country B demonym B + subject A Children in Australia \(\rightarrow\) Australian children Noun A + noun B The noun B + noun A Water consumption \(\rightarrow\) The consumption of water

Info

For another words \(\rightarrow\) Synonyms

docs.title: Word describe
docs.text:
• across
  • based on
  • in terms of = about

Example

  • male and female across 3 different age groups
  • leading mobile phone companies in terms of their global market share

docs.title: Samples
docs.text: ORIGINAL CHANGED The table below shows information about the monthly investment of American government in education in 2010. The provided table illustrates (data on the differences in) the amount of money allocated for education on a monthly basis by the government in America in the year 2010. The line graph below shows the percentage of travelers who visited four different attractions in Brighton in 2009. The given line graph depicts the proportion of many of tourists visiting four different spots over the course of years from 2000 to 2010. The bar chart gives information about the yearly spending on healthcare service by the government in America from 1970 to 1980. The provided bar chart shows data on the amount of money spent per year on medical-care service by the government in the US during the period spanning from 1970 to 1980. The given table illustrates the proportion of male and female cyclists based on 5 different age groups in the a certain area in the year 2011.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Abstract

Time period 
 - Changes (starting - ending point).
 - Comparison among the categories.
Discrete categories 
- Comparison among the categories.

Tip

Overview > 2 sentencesOverview = 1 sentence 
- Introduction 1 paragraph.
- Overview 1 paragraph.

- Introduction & overview 1 paragraph.

docs.title: Opening
docs.text:
• Overall, (it can be seen clearly from the chart)
  • Another highlight is that

docs.title: Key trends
docs.text:
TENDENCY VERB NOUN NOTE INCREASE - increase - rise - grow - go up - increase - rise - growth - upward trend rise \(\rightarrow\) V2 \(\rightarrow\) rose DECREASE - decrease - decline - drop - fall - go down - decrease - decline - drop - fall - downward trend - drop \(\rightarrow\) V2 \(\rightarrow\) dropped - fall \(\rightarrow\) V2 \(\rightarrow\) fell NO CHANGE - remain unchaged (stable/ constant) remain + almost 💯 (relatively 👀)

Warning

USING ALL V2 FOR KEY TRENDS !!!

docs.title: Describe adverb
docs.text:
STRONG WEAK - significantly - considerably - sharply - substantially - exponentially - noticeably - remarkably - slightly - moderately - marginally

Note

  • Intransitive verb \(\rightarrow\) adv + v | v + adv.
  • Transitive verb \(\rightarrow\) adv + VO | VO + adv.

docs.title: Structures
docs.text:
STRUCTURE NOTE EXAMPLE Subject Verb Adv The number of cars produced by company A increase sharply during the surveyed period. There was a adj noun (key trend) in subject Adj is Adv bonus above ☝️ changed to Adj form. In UK, there was a marginal rise in the investment in public services. - Categories witnessed (saw/ experenced) a adj noun (key trend) (in subject) - Subject witnessed (saw/ experienced) a adj noun (key trend) - Maybe use when you see loop word status. - While / whereas Beef consumption in England rose sharply, while France experienced a marginal fall throughout the surveyed period. Categories recorded (displayed) the highest/lowest subject - US recorded the highest proportion of spending on education. - Education in US recorded the highest proportion of spending. Subject 1 be (strong/weak) higher/lower than that in/on/at subject 2 - Strong: significantly, considerably, far, much. - Weak: slightly, a bit, a little. - That \(\rightarrow\) several \(\rightarrow\) those - Subject 1 is the best \(\rightarrow\) than the other countries (the remaining countries). - The proportion of students attending online classes at center A was much higher than that at center B. - UK men spent more time exercising than those in the US. - UK and US recorded a far higher proportion of spending on education than the other countries.

Note

  • With the exception of ...
  • Whereas the opposite ( the reverse) was true for ...
    • E.g. The market share of 3 companies, such as namely A,B, and C saw upward trend, whereas (while) the opposite was true for the remaining manufacturers.
  • With the most remarkable growth (rise) (being) recorded in ...
    • E.g. Oil production in all countries increased, with the most remarkable rise being recorded in Saudi Arabia.

docs.title: Advantage
docs.text: STRUCTURE NOTE EXAMPLE Subject have significant (beneficial/positive) impacts on sth Informal meaning \(\rightarrow\) A be good (beneficial/very important) for B. Parental support has significant impacts on the mental and emotional well-being of young children. Subject be crucial for sth crucial = very important Parental care is crucial for the the mental and emotional well-being of young children. Subject allow (enable) someone to verb allow (enable) = help Moving to major city allows the young to seek many better opportunities for personal and professional development. - One major benefit of Subject/Ving is the Noun/Noun-phrase (it offers) - One major benefit of Subject/Ving is that SVO - Using for general thing. - Above structure\(\rightarrow\) short description. - Below structure\(\rightarrow\) detail description. - Ving e.g. working from home. - major = significant = striking - it offers \(\rightarrow\) they offer. - One major benefit of online learning is the flexibility it offers. - One major benefit of online classes is the flexibility they offer. - One major benefit of online learning is that students can study at their own pace. - One major benefit someone can reap from subject is the Noun/Noun-phrase - One major benefit someone can reap from subject is that SVO Using for specific one. - Above structure\(\rightarrow\) short description. - Below structure\(\rightarrow\) detail description. - One major benefit students can reap from online learning is the flexibility it offers. - One major benefit students can reap from online learning is that they can study at their own pace. [Common useful phrases](advantage.md){.md-button}

docs.title: Disadvantage
docs.text: STRUCTURE NOTE EXAMPLE Subject have detrimental (adverse/negative) impacts on sth Informal meaning \(\rightarrow\) A be bad for (harmful to) B. Human activities have detrimental impacts on the environment. - Subject could lead to (result in) Noun/Noun-phrase - One major drawback of Subject is the Noun/Noun-phrase Short description. - Lack of exercise could lead to an sedentary lifestyle. - One major drawback of constructing industrial areas in the center is the noise pollution. One major drawback of Subject is that SVO Detail description. One major drawback of constructing industrial areas in the center is that environment will be polluted. [Common useful phrases](disadvantage.md){.md-button}
